Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Story: As I sat at the dinner table, my family’s voices buzzed around me, tossing out ideas for our weekend together—movie night, a hike, maybe even a board game marathon. My little brother’s eyes lit up as he pleaded for everyone to join, and Mom smiled at me, expecting my usual enthusiasm. But my phone vibrated in my pocket: a message from Alex, my boyfriend, reminding me that Saturday was our only free evening before he left for a week-long work trip. He wanted to cook dinner together, just the two of us, and I could almost hear the hope in his words. My heart twisted. I wanted to be there for my family, to laugh and make memories, but I also longed for that rare, quiet night with Alex. Both sides seemed to need me, and I felt the weight of their expectations pressing in, pulling me in two directions at once.
